Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Infectious Diseases (such as Viral Encephalitis, Hepatitis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Rheumatoid Lung Disease
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Viral Infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr Virus)
Diabetes Mellitus – considering the presence of alternating hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia, a potential sign of poorly controlled diabetes.
Sepsis – given leukocytosis and potential infection symptoms like cough, could indicate a systemic infection causing widespread organ dysfunction, possibly also affecting glucose metabolism.
Pneumonia – considering cough and leukocytosis which may suggest an infection, while fluctuations in blood sugar levels can occur during infections.
Chronic Kidney Disease – could potentially explain leukocytosis due to infection, disturbances in glucose metabolism, and might also be related to interstitial cystitis symptoms.
Interstitial Lung Disease – suggested by cough and might correlate with systemic symptoms (although less directly linked to glucose abnormalities).

Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) – particularly for its potential relation to interstitial cystitis and could also cause leukocytosis; might indirectly influence blood sugar levels through stress or infection.
Bronchitis – acute or chronic could present with cough and influence leukocytosis; may stress the body and affect glucose regulation.

Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) – can cause a wide range of systemic symptoms, including kidney involvement (thus possibly interstitial cystitis), leukocytosis, and could disturb glucose metabolism.
Cystic Fibrosis – especially in a younger age group, could explain the combination of symptoms through chronic infection (leading to leukocytosis), cough, and possibly affecting glucose metabolism.

Acute Pancreatitis – considering hyperglycemia as a sign of endocrine dysfunction, and leukocytosis due to inflammation; however, hypoglycemia is less commonly associated but could occur in the context of extensive pancreatic damage.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Glycemic lability is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause cysts, weight loss, and monocytosis due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause weight loss and monocytosis; cysts are less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to weight loss, and organ-specific forms can lead to cyst formation and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily affects the lungs but can also cause digestive issues leading to weight loss; cyst formation is a hallmark.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause weight loss and monocytosis; cystic bone lesions are also characteristic.

diagnoses.name: Cancer (Various Types)
diagnoses.reasoning: Tumors can cause cysts, significant weight loss, and dysphagia depending on their location.

diagnoses.name: Achalasia
diagnoses.reasoning: Specifically causes dysphagia and can lead to significant weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause weight loss and monocytosis; cysts are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Esophageal Cancer
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily causes dysphagia and significant weight loss.

diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis (initial phases can cause hyperthyroidism)
Thyrotoxicosis Factitia (excessive intake of thyroid hormones)
Urinary Tract Infection with systemic impact
Chronic viral infection (e.g., HIV, hepatitis C)
Kounis syndrome secondary to allergic reaction

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.details: PNES are episodes that resemble and are often misdiagnosed as epilepsy, but are psychological in origin. They may coexist with sleep disturbances, psychiatric disorders, or stress.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.details: Long-standing inflammation of the sinuses, often complicated by obstructive phenomena and can contribute to sleep disturbances due to difficulty breathing.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)
diagnoses.details: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing or periods of shallow breathing during sleep. It can lead to daytime fatigue and is linked with heart problems, stroke, and metabolic issues.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.details: A condition where too much iron builds up in the body (hyperferritinemia). It can lead to various organ damages. Thrombocytosis can also occur in this condition.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Neoplasms (MPNs)
diagnoses.details: A group of blood cancers where the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, platelets, or certain white blood cells. Both hyperferritinemia and thrombocytosis could be manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.details: A type of blood cancer that causes the marrow to make too many red blood cells. It can also lead to a high platelet count (thrombocytosis) and elevated ferritin levels.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Disorders
diagnoses.details: Chronic inflammation can lead to increased ferritin levels as it is an acute phase reactant. Conditions like rheumatoid arthritis must be explored.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.details: A disorder in which the body produces too many platelets. It can lead to complications such as blood clots or bleeding. High ferritin levels can sometimes be observed.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with Overlap Syndrome
diagnoses.details: COPD can lead to sleep-disordered breathing including obstructive sleep apnea. Overlap syndrome refers to the coexistence of OSA and COPD.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload Disorders
diagnoses.details: Conditions leading to excessive iron in the body, including hereditary diseases like hemochromatosis, or acquired conditions due to repeated transfusions, which can cause hyperferritinemia.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.reason: Arteriovenous malformations are a hallmark of HHT, which can also lead to various symptoms including migratory edema due to abnormal blood vessel formation. Patients may experience recurrent nosebleeds (which could be confused with or contribute to sinusitis symptoms) and, less commonly, skin sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It can lead to symptoms like sinusitis, various skin manifestations including edema, and might be linked to genital pain (vulvodynia) due to ulcerations.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Brainstem Aura
diagnoses.reason: Though not directly linked with all mentioned symptoms, this condition could possibly explain migraines, physical sensitivities, and some rare forms might involve edema. The connection to arteriovenous malformations and other symptoms might be coincidental or indicative of a complex migraine presentation.

diagnoses.name: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS)
diagnoses.reason: CRPS is a form of chronic pain that usually affects an arm or a leg. While not directly explaining all symptoms, it could account for migratory edema and physical sensitivities. Vulvodynia could be a manifestation of the chronic pain aspect in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: This inflammatory disease can affect any organ in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. In rare cases, it can cause skin problems (which might be interpreted as migratory edema), physical sensitivities, and complications leading to sinusitis. The connection to arteriovenous malformations and vulvodynia is less direct.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.reason: MCAS involves inappropriate release of mast cell mediators with varying symptoms including sinusitis, physical sensitivities, and potentially migratory edema. The connection to arteriovenous malformations and vulvodynia is more speculative.

diagnoses.name: Hughes-Stovin Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A rare syndrome that involves thrombophlebitis and multiple pulmonary and peripheral arteriovenous malformations. It could theoretically contribute to migratory edema and sinusitis due to circulatory and immune disruptions. The link to vulvodynia and physical sensitivities is less established.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reason: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria, Lyme disease can manifest a wide range of symptoms including migratory edema and physical sensitivities. Late-stage Lyme disease might mimic some of the vascular concerns associated with arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reason: While MS is primarily known as an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system, its wide range of symptoms can include physical sensitivities. Connections to sinusitis, migratory edema, arteriovenous malformations, and vulvodynia would be less direct and more coincidental.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It can explain the physical sensitivities and potentially the migratory edema, but the direct link to arteriovenous malformations, vulvodynia, and sinusitis would be more tenuous.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Chronic liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma)
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
Myeloproliferative neoplasms (e.g., essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera)
Cardiac disorders (e.g., atrial fibrillation, heart failure)

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the force of the blood against the artery walls is too high. Frequently has no symptoms but can lead to significant health issues.

diagnoses.name: Chest Pain
diagnoses.description: Can be caused by a variety of conditions from indigestion to heart attack. Requires immediate evaluation to determine the cause.

diagnoses.name: Osteoporosis
diagnoses.description: A bone disease that occurs when the body loses too much bone, makes too little bone, or both, leading to weak and brittle bones.

diagnoses.name: Kounis Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as 'allergic angina syndrome', it is a condition where acute coronary syndrome meets allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Onychodystrophy
diagnoses.description: Refers to the disfigurement of the fingernails or toenails. The condition can be a sign of skin disease, an infection or the result of injury.

diagnoses.name: Coronary Artery Disease
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the major blood vessels that supply your heart with blood, oxygen and nutrients become damaged or diseased. Could be related to or exacerbated by hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Acute Myocardial Infarction
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as a heart attack, occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked for a long enough time that part of the heart muscle is damaged or dies.

diagnoses.name: Angina Pectoris
diagnoses.description: A type of chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart, often a symptom of coronary artery disease.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder that can affect not just the joints but also the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and vessels, which may be associated with onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the heart can't pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. May be a long-term consequence of hypertension.

diagnoses: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) considering gastrointestinal symptoms
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Carbohydrate malabsorption (e.g., lactose or fructose intolerance)
Autonomic dysreflexia (in patients with spinal cord injury)
Acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (common cold)
Asthma (allergic asthma can cause symptoms like sneezing and rhinorrhoea)
Anaphylaxis (severe allergic reaction, though incontinence is less common, emergency)
Environmental allergy (e.g., to dust mites, mold, pet dander)
Urinary tract infection (especially if the primary symptom related to incontinence is urgency or discomfort, less likely related to other symptoms)
